title: Could artificial intelligence replace CEOs? - Quora

response.answer_text: Automation portends a different industrial environment than there is now. Some precedents have already occurred for personhood and as a board director. It might percolate from the bottom up if vehicles are classified as corporations to cover the regulations and events at arms length, and chatbots are used for official communications most often so it already seems like a systemic interface. The simplest firm could go from being run by an app to a bot and then the latest version like for claiming royalties or doing crypto mining. Machine learning still needs to be able to explain itself. If everyone had a sidekick bot, then so might the leader and its responsibilities, possibly rights, would be on a par. There are are some far-flung scenarios. An exec becomes a cyborg by then. Or someone who had a relationship left everything to it. Or the sovereignty puts all of the inactives under the wing of such a service for a while. Or the platforms offer an exec-level that others can subscribe to as outsource, but these want to avoid manipulation. International shells may want cut outs. Or anyone looking for a new exec can use a default machine in the meantime. Or someone finally uploaded to a virtual domain of such things. The same could be happening for admins in the other sectors. These are more like networks than single actors. The strongest argument would be if someone like the largest value outfit had one because global operations had become so complex that it took more than a single mind and that was equivalent to several orders of magnitude greater capability like a bureaucracy unto itself. Any dependents would then by linked to it by a botnet or something. If one gets knocked out by red tape, then another can take its place. The bots would be able to contract with other parties. Human execs would resist since they might see their competitive rewards drop, but might want to take over if a scenario was unforeseen and had not been trained in yet. Information could be combined from all sources like under climate events.

No, for the reason that it’s nearly impossible to predict and calibrate the exact behavior of people. It’s why “Moneyball” ultimately didn’t work. While you could look at baseball stats over a period of time, what ultimately failed was an inability to take into account such influencing factors as illness, home life, and attitudes about the game. Most of the role of a CEO has to do with understanding people. The subtleties of communication and sometimes the indirect way people talk. In some countries, it’s the indirect conversation that matters more than what’s said directly. I sit on the board of a company with a fellow CEO who tells me that his biggest challenge is getting to know his senior team well enough to get them properly, “calibrated,” as he put it, meaning before he fully understands not just their language, but the intention behind their language. I’m working with a company now that has one employee who’s a political animal and sees the world through the lens of company politics. His view of everything is based on political standing. He does very good work, but he’s forever thinking in terms of how he’s viewed by others. It means that everything he says requires the listener to take all of that into consideration. Something as simple as, “nice shirt” to him expressing it, is meant to suck-up, when we hear it as patronization and we ignore the comment, knowing full well he likely doesn’t mean it. I think there will be a time when those subtleties are taken into consideration in AI, but I think we’re very far from that. AI will have to learn how to sense mood, and us humans have difficulty with that right now. Then we have the whole matter of company strategy which can get extremely complicated for all the same reasons. Having been in embedded systems software, I can’t look inside any electronics device and not see all the relationships and politics that ultimately led to that design and finished product.

Only a highly advanced - totally futuristic- AI could do so. The CEO position requires many skills. Only an advanced AGI could posses these skills. Even then there would be problems. Let’s think about Elon Musk and Steve Jobs. The ability to motivate and inspire was (is) critical to their success. It is difficult to imagine an AI that could motivate or inspire. I’m not just talking about company employees here - Steve Jobs especially created a “reality distortion field” that drove buyers. Elon Musk arguably has a similar skill.

Possibly… Not anytime soon. Many jobs would likely be done first - take stock trading for instance… VERY heavy on the analysis, and timing of getting that analysis completed. How about the lawyers - their stock in trade is following rules and finding loop holes in rules. Prime candidate for AI. You still need somebody to show up in court, but the AI backing that person could be calling the shots. There are others that have similar activity. I would expect them before that of the CEO…

Lets rewrite this question as: Could AI replace everyone? And the the answer is yes, absolutely. There is nothing that true AI cannot do better than us which is what makes it so terrifying if it were ever to be misused. I’m not talking Terminator, although obviously the possibility remains, I am talking just straight up loss of purpose and destitution for the entire human race as AI start to take over our jobs. It’ll be the workers first, then the middle managers, then the CEOs.

AI does not replace anybody. What it does is make people more efficient by automating tasks. The effect of that in employment is that you need fewer staff to achieve the same job. Companies only have one CEO. The only way to get fewer than one is zero. That doesn’t seem realistic any time soon.
I just can't imagine how artificial intelligence is going to spend those millions of dollars in bonuses Maybe AI will hire some wall Street hookers. AI would say you could pull my plug anytime baby.
Yes, it doesn’t matter that the origin of the intelligence is artificial rather than natural. If intelligence can run a company, then … intelligence can run a company.
Why CEO only? It can replace even POTUS.
We only know theoretically what AI could possibly do, so theoretically yes it could.

It is practically very difficult to predict such change over a longer period as many things including our education, legal system, governance, business enterprise structure, economic system etc will change. In fact everything as we know today, even humanity, will change over a longer period.
In long term any thing happen. But my point is no
